doc.title: EVERCORE ISI
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/Twice in a Lifetime SP 500 Price Target 7750 at Year End 2026Twice in a Lifetime SP 500 Price Target 7750 at Year End 20_2025-08-31

passages.text: The idea that EVR ISI's Strategy Team has written this report in a number of locations (North Fork of Long Island, New Jersey and of course Evercore HQ at 55 E 52nd St. NY, NY) is testament to the connective and life altering power of the Internet Revolution. In fact, it is not a stretch to make the case that the economic consequences of the Pandemic might have been much more severe and long-lasting (Figure 3) had it not been for the ability of companies to connect themselves (Figure 4) and others through the Internet, once referred to as the World Wide Web.
Figure 3: The Internet Revolution Helped Turn the Pandemic From What Could Have Been an Economic Cataclysm Into Another Challenge Successfully Surrounded by a Connected World
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 4: Though Rightfully Declining in Focus as the Pandemic Moves Into the Rearview Mirror, WFH Wasn't Even "A Thing" Until 2020-21
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Yet this Revolution, the AI Revolution, is bigger.

It is bigger from a societal perspective because after having had the frame of reference of the Internet's transformational power, society (Don't we all use AI now? After all, it is now part of nearly every Google search) and business has been quick to "Adopt (Figure 5) and Adapt" to the potential of AI.
Figure 5: AI Corporate Adoption on Pace to Reach 25% in 2025 a Mere 3 Years After ChatGPT Was Introduced to the World
Source: Census Bureau, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 6: AI Adoption, Virtually Everywhere by 2028, While the "Bear Case" Has Already Been Laid to Rest
Source:Evercore ISI Research
In our original work on AI in 2023 we identified 2025 as the inflection year for AI on the way to a corporate base case adoption rate of \(67\%\) in 2028 (Figure 6).
AI has demonstrated its "use case" merit across virtually all Industries (Figure 7) driven by AI's ability to "think" (Autonomous agents/Agentic AI).
Figure 7: Share of Each Job's Functions Exposed to AI, by Industry
Source:O'NET, BLS, Census, Felten et al. (2021),Evercore ISI Research

As important in a world constrained by demographic headwinds (Figures 8 and 9) to labor is AI's ability to "act", stepping into the domains where we work and leveraging the same tools we use to produce goods and services.
Figure 8: The Supply of Labor Is Falling Globally
Source:UN Population Prospects,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 9: More Consumers Relative to Workers Producing Goods Stresses Production
Source:UN Population Prospects,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 10: More AI Used in Clinical Trials
Source:World Bank,Evercore ISI Research

From Technology to Finance to Industry to Health Care, where AI is used to ease administrative burdens, freeing up medical professionals' time to treat patients as well as test drugs (Figure 10), AI is everywhere, improving people's lives.
Figure 11: Buried Beneath the Lesson Plan
Source:OECD,Evercore ISI Research
And the more we learn about AI, the more we are able to learn, better and more equitably, as AI transforms the Education system, freeing teachers up to teach and mentor (Figure 11) ...
... while transforming the Educational Access and Cost structure across a number of different dimensions (Figure 12).
Figure 12: Scaling Up Access, Scaling Down Cost
Source:Evercore ISI Research
Al is everywhere, in every industry.
If you don't believe us, turn to the ultimate arbiter, the equity market.
In an investment sense since the bull market beginning in October 2022, Al is larger and more pervasive than the Internet from 1995- 2000 ever was.
Figure 13: For Much of the 1990's It Was "All Tech, All the Time" at the Expense of Everything Else
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

In the late 1990's, the stock market wealth was concentrated largely in Technology stocks, which day in and day out, saw the broad market unable to maintain the bullish cadence as cumulative advance/declines peaked 2 years before the Dot.Com bubble burst (Figure 13).

In 2025, the advance/decline line has kept pace with and frequently led the S&P 500 higher, in the ultimate manifestation of what can best be described as a Stock Market Participatory Democracy (Figure 14).

Indeed in 2025, in contrast to the late 1990's, Utilities (Those best able to be conduits providing power to Al data centers and other similar buildouts) and Industrials (The facilitators for the Global Al buildout) have participated in the Al- driven S&P 500 Bull market, alongside Tech (Figure 15).
Figure 14: The "Al Revolution Bull" - a Unique Version of a Participatory Democracy Amongst Stocks
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 15: The Al "Trade" (Not a Trade but a Long Term Structural Buy and Hold Investment Theme) Touches Everything. Utilities - Who Knew in 2022?
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 16: The AI Revolution Bull is Mag-nificent
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research

All this is not to say that Technology isn't dominant. Like the Internet Bull market, it is - with huge outperformance (Figure 16) and the top 5 companies in the S&P 500 at \(28\%\) of the Index weight dwarfing any previous concentration peaks on record, Y2K or otherwise.
There is a school of thought that says the majority of the AI- driven Bull market gains have been seen in this cycle.
We disagree, and thus introduce a year end 2026 price target for the S&P 500 of 7,750, \(27x\) an EPS of \(\) 287\(for 2026.
Figure 17: As the Internet Helped Lift Productivity, So Too Will AI
Source:Haver,Evercore ISI Research

The "details" of the Internet Bull market of 1995- 2000 - a time where innovation drove productivity gains which fuller implementation of AI will also drive in time (Figure 17) - make it easier to understand our logic for expecting further multiple expansion alongside increased earnings driving what we forecast to be a \(24\%\) gain beyond our new Year End 2025 S&P 500 Price Target of 6,250.
Twice in a Lifetime is eminently possible.
Figure 18: It Isn't Y2K's 28x, But in 2025-26, Once in a Lifetime Will Become Twice
Source:Bloomberg,Factset,Evercore ISI Research
The Internet Bull market was a Revolution led by Technology resulting in a broad market multiple that was among the highest ever at 28x LTM EPS (Figure 18).

And like the Internet Revolution Bull (Figure 19), the AI Revolution Bull in its recent vintage has had an accommodating Fed to help things along (Figure 20). The critical difference being that in 2025- 26 a Fed that is increasingly carrying President Trump's imprimatur is not going to hike rates at any time before the 2026 Midterm elections, regardless of the "economic brew".
Figure 19: The Fed Was Accommodative in the Heart of the Internet Revolution Until It Felt the Need to "Fight" the Bubble Forming in 1999, Which Ultimately Led to the Dot.Com Bust
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 20: The Fed Rate Cut Cycle Returns to a Theater Near You on September 17, With Further "Showings" Ahead in 2026
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
In fact, the "risk" of a Bubble that could see the S&P 500 rise to 9,000 in 2026 is increased by a Fed which could overstimulate an economy still battling Pandemic echo and now Tariff echo inflation.

Putting the Internet Revolution and the AI Revolution in context, the cyclical Bear Markets both had as a result of exogenous influences (Russian Debt Default and LTCM Crisis in 1998, "Tariff Tantrum" in 2025) and the speed of the Non-Recession Bear Market recovery on the Rollercoaster to new highs suggest that the average expected rally in 2025-26 is an additional 18 months with a gain of 26% (Figure 21) ... hence 7,750 at Year End 2026.
Figure 21: Bear Markets Then New Highs and What Happens on the Rollercoaster Afterward. More Gains, But Volatility Stays Along for the Ride As Well
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
This rally may or may not end in a Bubble. 2021's Bull Market didn't, 2007's did in Housing though not in Stocks, and of course Y2K's was the Biggest Bubble up until that time.
Figure 22: Flash Survey Results - "Has a Bubble in the U.S. Equity Market Begun to Inflate?"
Source: Evercore ISI Surveys, Evercore ISI Research

Our expectation, and Yours, given that a majority \((64\%)\) of You believe a Bubble in U.S. Equities has begun to inflate (Figure 22) is that the AI Revolution, like the Internet Revolution before it, will end in a Bubble. We will keep asking You this question, sensitive to "Yes" responses outside of a \(50\%\) to \(80\%\) range as signs a Bubble is becoming heavily inflated/in danger of bursting.
Figure 23: Every Structural Bull Market of the Last 25+ Years Has Ended With a Capital Markets Surge. The "AI Revolution" Surge Lies Ahead.
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

But before a Bubble expands and ultimately bursts, this Bull Market has a period of "rational exuberance" ahead of it, marked by the type of robust capital markets activity that has accompanied every major Structural bull market of the last 25 years in late stages, 2021, 2007, 2000 - but not yet this one (Figure 23). This is still ahead.
Figure 24: Above Covid Uncertainty Spike Sinks to Normalcy
Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research

Summer 2025 will be remembered as the quarter when tax and tariff uncertainty gave way to clarity (Figure 24), even as the full extent of the financial and economic consequences remain on the horizon.

2Q Earnings Season completed the first half Blowout (488 S&P 500 companies have reported), with S&P 500 Earnings Growth of 11.8% and Sales Growth of 6.5%, surprising by 7.6% and 2.2% respectively (Figure 25).
Figure 25: Q2 '25 Earnings Growth & Surprise Snapshot
Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 26: Beat Rates Climb to Covid-Reopening Highs
Source:Factset,Evercore ISI Research
The index- level beat rate was exceptional, with \(83\%\) of the index reporting positive earnings surprises and \(81\%\) of companies reporting positive sales surprises (Figure 26).

These strong results were not coincidental. Entering the season, analysts had slashed forecasts sharply under the weight of tariff headlines and policy uncertainty, only to watch companies hurdle over the (low) bar set.

Concerns that tariffs would immediately and significantly erode revenues and margins didn't materialize. Corporate margins demonstrated resilience in the first half of the year (Figure 27), supported by robust sales growth (Figure 28). Strong performance has bolstered expectations for sustained SPS growth in the second half, although profit margin expectations remain subdued.
Figure 27: 1H Margins Defy Initial Fears, Remain Near Peaks Though. Compression Risks Remain.
Source:Factset,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 28: Top Line Strength Fuels Back Half Outlook
Source:Factset,Evercore ISI Research

The impact of tariffs varied due to differing inventory cycles, staggered tariff implementation dates, customer pull- forward, and inconsistent enforcement rates. Additionally, companies mitigated tariff effects through strategic negotiations with suppliers, supply chain adjustments, price pass- throughs to customers, and cost- cutting measures.

While CEO confidence remains subdued though recovering (Figure 29), the evolution of S&P 500 guidance in the first half of the year paints a far more upbeat picture, as management earnings estimates not only remain intact but surge higher — propelled by an outsized wave of upward revisions in Q2 and a sharp decline in downward adjustments (Figure 30).
Figure 29: C-Suite Confidence Creeps Back From the Abyss ...
Source: Chief Executive Magazine, Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 30: ... While Corporate Outlooks Climb Relentlessly
Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research

Upside surprises and improved guidance have resulted in strong upward estimate revisions (Figure 31) with EVR ISI Strategy outperform sectors Communication Services, Information Technology and Consumer Discretionary leading the charge (Figure 32).
Figure 31: Estimate Gravity Defiance Reemerges
Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 32: Upward Revisions Finds its Engine in AI and Services Tilted Sectors
Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 33: From April Showers to Summer Sun, Economic Forecasts Brighten
Following a period of Tariff induced caution earlier this year, we revise our estimates upward in light of robust fundamentals and a more constructive macro backdrop (Figure 33).
Figure 34: 2025 Marks Al Adoption Inflection Year
Source:Census Bureau,Evercore ISI Research
The strength of Q2 earnings results has exceeded expectations, particularly among companies with exposure to Al, where momentum continues to build (Figure 34).

The introduction of the OBBB framework is likely to prove supportive, with an estimated \(41.5\%\) of incremental cash flows directed toward share repurchases (Figure 35). This capital allocation dynamic provides a steady, moderate tailwind to EPS in 2025 and 2026 (Figure 36).
Figure 35: S&P 500 use of incremental cash flow post-TCJA, 2019-19 - An OBBB Guide
Source:Factset,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 36: Net Share Repurchases likely to Support 2025 and 2026 EPS
Real Estate, Utilities OBBB Benefits Not Applicable Source:Factset,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 37: Uncertainty Retreats As Agreements Anchor Outlook
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

Moreover, less uncertainty (Figure 37) supported by trade agreements have helped to mitigate tariff- related headwinds, reducing pressures and contributing to a more favorable economic outlook relative to earlier in the year. Together, these factors underpin a stronger- than- anticipated earnings trajectory.
Figure 38: EVR ISI Strategy S&P 500 EPS Target
Source:Factset, Evercore ISI Research

Reflecting these developments, we are raising our 2025 S&P 500 EPS estimate to \(264 (from\) 255 previous forecast) and our 2026 EPS estimate to \(287 (from\) 272 previous forecast), implying \(8.7\%\) and \(8.6\%\) earnings growth (Figure 38). These estimates capture the solid earnings power of U.S. corporates in an environment characterized by Al- driven growth, supportive fiscal and easing monetary policy, and a stabilizing global trade landscape.

Earnings growth has returned for the 493 but leadership remains concentrated. The Mag 7 still contributes a disproportionate share even as their YoY growth falls from early- 2024 peaks, while the 493 advances on a steadier, single- digit path (Figure 39). In semiconductors, it remains a tale of two markets. The High Performance Compute complex — accelerators and GPUs, high- bandwidth memory, and leading- edge foundry with advanced packaging — that supports AI workloads continues to outperform relentlessly off the broader market bottom (Figure 40).
Figure 39: Concentrated Strength Amid Broad-Based Growth
Source:Factset, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 40: Silicon Divide Widening
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

In a recent EVR ISI Strategy report on AI adoption across industries, developed in partnership with Zack Kass, the former Head of Go- To- Market at OpenAI, we highlight how AI is supporting corporate margins in diverse ways. In Financials, firms are automating back- and middle- office processes like compliance, fraud detection, and risk modeling, transforming costly manual workflows into scalable utilities; in Food Retail, AI is enhancing demand forecasting, inventory management, and delivery logistics to reduce waste and improve store productivity, with Kroger a notable example; and in Logistics and Shipping, AI is boosting fleet uptime and cutting costs, reinforcing both operating margins and supply chain resilience.
Figure 41: Margins Remain Resilient with AI Providing Further Support
Source: DataInsight, Evercore ISI Research

While U.S. corporate profit margins have historically cycled with the broader economy, since 2010, they continue to make and sustain record highs (Figure 41). Against this backdrop, AI has the potential to provide further support, offering a new structural driver of efficiency that could sustain margins and potentially extend them beyond their current plateau.
Figure 42: AI Climbing the Corporate Agenda
Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research

AI now sits among the top priorities on the corporate agenda, with mentions rising across earnings calls, conferences, investor days, and filings (Figure 42). Management teams increasingly frame the opportunity as enterprise- wide, spanning automation and decision support, product redesign and personalization, new data- driven revenue streams, and reworked cost structures.

EVR ISI Strategy continues to see value in companies most directly and positively exposed to the AI transformation. Accordingly, we recommend anchoring portfolios around our refreshed AI Enablers, Adapters, and Adopters below. These are the firms that are not only building the infrastructure to support AI, but also those integrating it strategically and scaling it effectively across their operations.

EVR ISI Strategy screens the Russell 3000 on three focus areas: AI engagement, earnings estimates, and valuation. We benchmark each company's last- four- quarters (L4Q) AI mentions — across calls, conferences, investor days, and filings — against a proprietary baseline from its AI Exposure Score, screening in names that exceed that baseline by \(100+\) mentions (i.e., talking about AI far more than their business mix would imply). We then require YTD upward revisions to 2026 EPS consensus, a minimum market cap of \(\) 2B\(, and finally screen in only stocks trading below their own five- year average NTM P/E. The result (Figure 43, p. 17) is an attractively valued cohort with elevated AI focus and improving fundamentals.
Figure 43:Al Enablers, Adopters, and Adapters

Source: Bloomberg, Factset, Evercore ISI Research

Recurring, but ultimately temporary, Scares are a Feature, not a Bug in the ongoing AI Revolution. Near the third anniversary of ChatGPT's launch bringing the AI Revolution to light, every month or so seemingly brings a scare that challenges the structural AI thesis. Whether it's a research paper casting doubt on the technology's capabilities or performance, hiring freezes (ironically often seen as both a result of AI and the cause of more AI), or investor skepticism around the likes of capex spending or scaling laws, the narrative cycling through phases of optimism and caution, with caution often garnering more attention.

To the casual observer, these scares look like signs of an extended bubble at risk of a “reality check”, even feeling like a “coronary” in the moment; DC Policy volatility also adding to the AI Revolution Bull Market's “coronary” narrative in 2025. But for those who have studied the history of Bull Market technological revolutions, these palpitations are often less urgent than they appear on the surface. Whether induced by deviations from expectations at the sector level or in bellwethers, by macro catalysts, or even fluctuations in sentiment, they are a natural part of secular technological adoption trends being stress- tested in real time.
Figure 44: Tech Corrections a Feature of the Dotcom Bull, Blips in Hindsight
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

Case in point, the Dotcom boom of the late 1990s regularly saw Nasdaq/Tech pullbacks of \(10\%\) or more (Figure 44), including the Asian FX crisis, Russian debt default, and LTCM collapse. Each time the Internet- driven Bull market reasserted itself – until of course the March 2000 Bubble Peak, which need not be the fate of the AI Bull (and even then, Tech reestablished its leadership after a hiatus).
Figure 45: DeepSeek Triggered an AI Coronary in January 2025
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

The current AI cycle has no shortage of its own “Scares” to point to. The biggest Technological so far has been the revelation that DeepSeek produced a GenAI model that purported to rival its established competitors at a fraction of the cost, causing a reassessment of chip demand vs. investment (Figure 45).

Concerns stemming from the scale of AI infrastructure buildup (Figure 46), one of the largest in history – hyperscalers are projected to invest \(375 billion in just 12 months (Figure 47) – have at sporadically given investors pause. Efforts to secure financing for these ventures have underscored some strain, with firms like SoftBank and other capital providers balking at the scale of commitments required, and Elon Musk himself openly questioning the feasibility of such massive deployments.
Figure 46: Hyperscalers Expected To Put Their Money Where their Mouth Is
Note: Hyperscalers defined as MSFT, META, GOOGL, AMZN, TSLA, AAPL & ORCL. Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 47: Stargate Among Earth's Biggest Bets
Note: * Indicates Expected Cost Given Ongoing Project. Source: Wikipedia, Evercore ISI Research
Every earnings season, commentary or results from one company or another are pointed to as cracks forming in the trend (Figure 48) – almost always a result of falling short of a very high bar.
Figure 48: AI Slowdown Concerns a Recurring Earnings Season Occurrence
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Yet strong absolute performance of the broader sector has proven the driving force.

And most recently, a much-publicized MIT report from summer 2025 found that nearly 95% of custom GenAI pilots were failing to create measurable business value (Figure 49). While a "coronary"- worthy development on the surface, the largest impediment was unwillingness to adopt AI tools, organizational inertia, rather than the effectiveness of the technology itself (Figure 50). Additionally, the number of pilots being run is itself a testament to interest in AI's potential, and failures a part of the proving ground in early technological adoption.
Figure 49: Ambition Outpacing Adoption
Source: MIT, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 50: Entrenched Corporate Habits a Barrier to Adoption
Respondents were asked to rate each issue on a scale of 1-10. Source: MIT, Evercore ISI Research
Of course, there has been the Macro Driven policy volatility (Figure 51), disturbing the AI Revolution Bull Market (Figure 52) but by no means derailing it.
Figure 51: With Tariff Regimes Subsequently Moderated, April's "Liberation Day" Largely Served to Liberate Low Conviction Longs from Positions
Source: Census Bureau, US ITC, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 52: Policy Volatility Fed Directly into Market Volatility Resulting in April's Historic Buying Opportunity
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 53: The Macro Volatility is Elevating in September as the President and the Fed Seize the Headlines
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
And there is certainly more episodic volatility ahead, particularly in light of the ongoing tension between President Trump and the Federal Reserve (Figure 53).
But in thinking about the Structural AI Bull market, such episodic dislocations must be seen as buying opportunities.

That's because any near term correction, or subsequent pullback on the way to 7,750 at Year End 2026 is not the "stuff" of structural multi- year Bear Markets - deep financial distresses, imbalances resulting in Recessions, a Fed tightening policy, a federal government tightening fiscal policy (especially unlikely into the Midterms).

Through all of the ebbs and flows (Figure 54) previous and ahead, the secular AI Revolution has pulled through and will continue to move forward. For reference, an index of AI Semiconductors (Phlx AI Semiconductor Index, ASOX) is up \(+18.9\%\) YTD vs. SPX \(+9.8\%\) , and \(+340\%\) from the October 2022 market trough vs. SPX \(+80\%\) (Figure 55).
Figure 54: Nothing, Not Even the AI Bull, Moves in a Straight Line
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 55: The AI Bull Continues to Charge
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research

All this to say that even in the strongest of Bull markets and the most enduring of secular themes, stress tests of both the thesis and price trend are inevitable. This reality in mind, we raise our 2025e S&P 500 price target to 6,250 (from 5,600) - 23.7x on \(\) 264\(EPS e, in line with the historical revision to consensus over the remainder of the year - our outlook factoring the likelihood of another"Scare" - whether catalyzed by macro, Seasonality, AI "doubts" or any number of obstacles - driving near term episodic volatility before the AI- driven Bull resumes its charge to our 2026 price target of 7,750.

It also underscores the importance of risk management and optionality to weathering the "Scares" and staying invested for the long term; with the alternative for long horizon buy and hold investors being to be in position to "embrace the volatility" and buy a dip that historically could extend as deep as \(- 7\%\) to \(- 15\%\) before a typical year end rally takes hold.
Figure 56: Buy Options When VIX Is Low (Now), Buy Stocks When VIX Is Higher
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

For investors who can utilize options, implied volatility priced near its cheapest of the year (Figure 56) makes buying Index Put Protection and Calls for stock replacement on Al Leaders especially attractive.

For stocks specifically, optionality means complementing a structural Al- centric portfolio with a selective Valuation tilt - the factor has a track record of leading, both across factors and versus itself, when stock market multiples are as expensive as they are currently (Figure 57). Health Care, which trades at a slight discount to its long term average multiple (Figure 58) vs. S&P 500 at a sizable premium, features prominently in Valuation factor screens.
Figure 57: Valuation Factor Attractive When Market Multiple Expensive
Data since 1990 Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 58: Health Care Trades at a Valuation Discount in an Expensive Market
Source: Factset, Evercore ISI Research

EVR ISI Strategy's upside Bull Case sees the S&P 500 ending 2026 at 9,000, with a 30x trailing P/E multiple on \(\) 300\(2026e EPS. This scenario is predicated on the formation of an asset market bubble. And not just any bubble, but the Biggest Bubble Ever.
Figure 59: S&P 500 +40% in 12 Months - Uncommon, but Not Unheard Of
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

9,000, up \(44\%\) over EVR ISI Strategy's 2025e PT of 6,250 - just outside of the top 1 percentile of S&P 500 12 month returns historically (Figure 59), even rarer excluding recoveries from Bear Markets and/or Recessions.

Think it can't happen? Asset bubbles of material significance have inflated, in some pocket of the market, repeatedly over the past 25 years - each to a degree previously unimaginable at least relative to their own respective histories, if not absolutely.
Figure 60: 1990s Dotcom Bubble
Normalized to 10/8/1998 Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

The Dotcom Bubble of the late 1990's propelled a Bull market that annualized \(+38\%\) in the S&P 500 from the October 1998 trough to the March 2000 peak, and \(+165\%\) in the Nasdaq 100 (Figure 60).
Figure 61: Early 2000s Housing Bubble
Normalized to 10/9/2002 Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research

The U.S. Housing Bubble of the early 2000's saw Homebuilders rise \(+70\%\) annualized from the October 2002 broad market bottom to the sector's July 2005 top (Figure 61). The S&P 500 advanced at a more "modest" \(+18\%\) .
China's speculative Equity Market Bubble that peaked in June 2015 advanced at a \(+117\%\) annualized rate from its March 2014 low (Figure 62).

And the Global Bond Bubble of 2018- 2020 - the current holder of the Biggest Bubble Ever title - defied conventional wisdom with over \(\) 18T\(, 25\%\) of the World's debt market, yielding negative interest (Figure 63).
Figure 62: Mid 2010s China Equity Bubble
Normalized to 3/20/2014 Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 63: Global Bond Bubble - The Biggest Bubble Ever
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research

The S&P 500 ending 2026 with \(\) 300\(EPS implies a third consecutive year of robust earnings growth, and an unusually flat revision to current\) \ \(303\) consensus bucking the historic downward trend (Figure 64). The 30x trailing multiple would set records on its own, surpassing Y2K's 28x peak (Figure 65).
Figure 64: It Would Take a Bull to Buck Established Trend of Lower EPS Estimate Revisions
Source:Factset,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 65:Meant to Be Broken? S&P 500 30x Trailing P/E Would Be a New Record
Source:Bloomberg,Factset,Evercore ISI Research
These together would require an extraordinary set of circumstances. Such a setup is not out of the realm of possibility by the end of 2026.
The Fed is looking to resume a cut cycle priced by markets to extend through next year (Figure 66).
Fiscal stimulus is set to become a tailwind for stocks and the economy ahead of U.S. Midterm elections, on top of modest but meaningful OBBB Benefits.
And retail investors have exhibited a revival of speculative appetite (Figure 67).
Figure 66: Fed Funds Pricing Resumed Rate Cut Cycle Through 2026
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 67:Speculation Acceleration
Source:FINRA,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 68: Business Confidence Pressured
Meanwhile, Animal Spirits – Confidence – have been restrained for Businesses (Figure 68) ...
Figure 69: Consumer Confidence Pressured
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
... the Consumer (Figure 69) ...
Figure 70: Investor Sentiment Still "Rationally Exuberant"
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
... and Investors (Figure 70) alike ...
... on the other hand meaning upside to Bubble levels, the Dotcom era often cited as the compare with today's Tech- driven market drawing similarities.
Figure 71: M&A Activity Turning the Corner?
Source: Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
A dynamic July and seasonally strong August for M&A activity (Figure 71) have raised hopes for a revived capital markets cycle, a defining feature and driver of Bubble conditions in the modern era.
And with all waves of Irrational Exuberance, it would begin with a Rational notion taken "too far".
Figure 72: Al Success Story, the Substrate for Extended Market Expectations?
Source: Factset, Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research

Today, a release of Animal Spirits is most likely to be underpinned by the AI Revolution - ongoing adoption has already produced margin expansion in Enablers (Figure 72) and is expected to boost broader profitability as efficiency gains are realized, which may then be extrapolated to unattainable extremes in the Bull Case Bubble scenario.

EVR ISI Strategy's downside Bear Case sees the S&P 500 ending 2026 at 5,000. This scenario is predicated on Stagflation materializing in the economy and metastasizing into markets already trading at elevated valuations.
Figure 73: Trade War 2.0 Stokes Stagflation Fears

While the economy has been resilient to price pressures and growth headwinds from tariff and Uncertainty that had been feared at the height of Trade War 2.0 tensions in April (Figure 73), the spectre of Stagflation has hung over markets since.
Figure 74: Stagflation Concerns Sticky
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
Concerns have resurfaced over the past month (Figure 74) ...

... first with a Payrolls report not only adding an anemic 73K jobs in July but seeing a steep - 258K downward revision over 2 months (Figure 75), then by a much stronger than expected PPI print (Figure 76) - a shock following benign CPI.
Figure 75: Payrolls Deceleration - The "Stag" Risk
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 76: PPI Acceleration - The "Flation" Risk
Source:Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research
Indeed, EVR ISI's Eco Team forecasts 2026 GPD of \(+1.5\%\) 4Q YoY and Core PCE of \(+3.3\%\) , a mix of slow growth and elevated inflation that crosses into Stagflationary territory.
Figure 77: Stocks Dislike Stagflation
Source: Bloomberg, Evercore ISI Research
The S&P 500 on average falls \(- 10\%\) on an annualized basis when GDP QoQ growth is between \(0\%\) and \(+1.5\%\) , and Core PCE is \(3\%\) or higher YoY (Figure 77).

But with trailing P/E at \(24.9x\) among its highest outside of the Dotcom Bubble, downside risk to stocks would likely be more pronounced – elevated multiples have a documented history of being a headwind to forward stock returns, but absolute and relative (Figure 78).
Figure 78: S&P 500 Forward Return Are Weak When Valuations Are Elevated – Down and Out in Years 2 and 3 at 24x
Source: Bloomberg, Factset, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 79: P/E – Even a Return to “Average” Would Be Felt By Markets
Source:Factset, Bloomberg,Evercore ISI Research

The 5,000 Bear Case scenario is \(- 23\%\) below the S&P 500's 8/30 close of 6,460. Assuming EPS grows at EVR ISI Econ's \(+1.5\%\) GDP forecast in 2026 to – still positive but well below the average annual rate – translates to a trailing P/E multiple of \(18.7x\) for the year, effectively a reversion to its \(18.8x\) average since 1990 (Figure 79).

series.name: Instructional Labor Efficiency
values: AI tutors deliver core explanations and real-time practice, reducing the burden on teachers to repeat material. This expands the effective reach of each educator, allowing for larger or more diverse classrooms without compromising learning quality.

series.name: Personalized & Automated Assessment and Feedback
values: LLMs can evaluate open-ended responses, track mastery in real time, and guide personalized remediation, making learning more adaptive while saving hours of manual grading and reducing the need for large-scale standardized exams.

series.name: Accelerated Curriculum Development and Localization
values: Generative models adapt content across languages, grade levels, and cultural contexts, eliminating the need for expensive textbook production and update cycles. Curricula once refreshed every decade can now evolve in real time.

series.name: Dropout Prevention and Remediation
values: When struggling students receive timely, personalized support, they are less likely to fall behind, repeat grades, or exit the education system entirely, avoiding costly interventions later down the pipeline.

series.name: Teacher Training
values: AI-driven simulations, virtual feedback tools, and personalized coaching accelerate skill acquisition and reduce dependency on in-person instruction, especially critical in regions with limited teacher supply.
